[[Ashutosh Saxena]] | nationality = British | children = 2 }} {{Infobox Chinese | t = 吳恩達 | s = 吴恩达 | p = Wú Ēndá | j = ng4 jan1 daat6 }} '''Andrew Yan-Tak Ng''' ({{zh|t=吳恩達}}; born 1976) is a British-American [[computer scientist]] and [[Internet Entrepreneur|technology entrepreneur]] focusing on [[machine learning]] and [[artificial intelligence]] (AI). Ng was a cofounder and head of [[Google Brain]] and was the former Chief Scientist at [[Baidu]], building the company's Artificial Intelligence Group into a team of several thousand people.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/22/business/baidu-artificial-intelligence-andrew-ng.html|title=A.I. Expert at Baidu, Andrew Ng, Resigns From Chinese Search Giant |last=Mozur|first=Paul|date=March 22, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=April 17, 2019|issn=0362-4331}} Ng is an [[adjunct professor]] at [[Stanford University]] (formerly [[associate professor]] and Director of its [[Stanford AI Lab]] or SAIL). Ng has also worked in the field of [[online education]], cofounding [[Coursera]] and DeepLearning.AI.{{cite web|url=https://www.coursera.org/instructor/andrewng |title=Andrew Ng – Stanford University |website=Coursera |access-date=August 29, 2017}} He has spearheaded many efforts to "democratize deep learning" teaching over 8 million students through his online courses.{{Citation|title=Andrew Ng at Amazon re: MARS 2019|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j2nGxw8sKYU |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211220/j2nGxw8sKYU |archive-date=2021-12-20 |url-status=live|language=en|access-date=2019-11-20}}{{cbignore}}{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/4032920/baidus-head-of-artificial-intelligence-is-stepping-down|title=Baidu's head of artificial intelligence is stepping down|last=Terdiman|first=Daniel|date=March 22, 2017|website=Fast Company|access-date=April 17, 2019}} Ng is renowned globally in computer science, recognized in [[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]'s 100 Most Influential People in 2012 and [[Fast Company|Fast Company's]] Most Creative People in 2014. His influence extends to being named in the [[Time 100|Time100]] AI Most Influential People in 2023. In 2018, he launched and currently heads the AI Fund, initially a $175-million investment fund for backing artificial intelligence startups. He has founded Landing AI, which provides AI-powered [[SaaS]] products.{{cite web|url=https://landing.ai/|title=Home|website=Landing AI|access-date=April 17, 2019}} On April 11, 2024, [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] announced the appointment of Ng to its board of directors.{{Cite web |date=2024-04-11 |title=Amazon adds AI expert Andrew Ng to board as GenAI race heats up |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/retail-consumer/amazon-sees-opportunity-lower-costs-fulfillment-network-ceo-says-2024-04-11/ |website=Reuters}} == Biography == Ng was born in the [[United Kingdom]],{{cite news|last=Seligman|first=Katherine|title=If Andrew Ng could just get his robot to assemble an Ikea bookshelf, we'd all buy one|url=http://www.sfgate.com/magazine/article/If-Andrew-Ng-could-just-get-his-robot-to-assemble-2484400.php|publisher=[[SFGate]]|access-date=February 12, 2013|date=December 3, 2006}} in 1976 to Ronald Paul Ng, a hematologist and [[Tisa Ho]], an arts administrator,{{cite news |last1=Ng |first1=Terry |title=After His Son Co-Founded Coursera, He Became Its Earliest Student and Completed 146 Courses |url=https://www.ricemedia.co/culture-people-after-son-cofounded-coursera-became-earliest-student-completed-146-courses/ |publisher=Rice Media |date=September 26, 2020}}{{cite news |title=Healer, teacher |url=https://www.asiaone.com/health/healer-teacher |access-date=25 February 2022 |publisher=The Straits Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231110052610/https://www.asiaone.com/health/healer-teacher |archive-date=2023-11-10 |url-status=dead}}{{cite journal |last1=Miquiabas |first1=Bong |title=A.I. and the New Era of Business |journal=The Peak Magazine Hong Kong |date=July 2015 |pages=40–45 |url=https://www.cs.cityu.edu.hk/~hwchun/AIProjects/pdf/The%20Peak%20-%20AI%20-%20small.pdf}} who were both immigrants from [[Hong Kong]]. He has at least one brother. In his youth, Ng lived in Hong Kong and Singapore. Ng attended and graduated from [[Raffles Institution]].{{citation needed |date=May 2024}} In 1997, he earned his undergraduate degree with a triple major in [[computer science]], [[statistics]], and [[economics]] from [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]]. Between 1996 and 1998 he also conducted research on [[reinforcement learning]], [[model selection]], and [[feature selection]] at the AT&T [[Bell Labs]]. In 1998, Ng earned his [[master's degree]] in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT) in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. At MIT, he built the first publicly available, automatically indexed web-search engine for research papers on the web. It was a precursor to [[CiteSeerX]]/[[ResearchIndex]], but specialized in machine learning. In 2002, he received his [[Doctor of Philosophy]] (Ph.D.) in Computer Science from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], under the supervision of [[Michael I. Jordan]]. His thesis is titled "Shaping and policy search in [[reinforcement learning]]" and is well-cited to this day.{{cite web|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~ang/curriculum-vitae.pdf|title=Cirriculum Vitae: Andrew Y. Ng|last=Ng|first=Andrew}}{{cite thesis |last=Ng |first=Andrew |date=2003 |url=http://rail.eecs.berkeley.edu/deeprlcourse-fa17/docs/ng-thesis.pdf |title=Shaping and policy search in Reinforcement Learning |website=Robotic AI & Learning Lab (RAIL) |publisher=University of California, Berkeley}} He started working as an assistant professor at [[Stanford University]] in 2002 and as an associate professor in 2009.{{Cite web|last=Ng|first=Andrew Y.|date=May 20, 2015|title=Curriculum Vitæ: Andrew Y. Ng|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~ang/curriculum-vitae.pdf|access-date=October 9, 2020|website=Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory}} He currently lives in [[Los Altos Hills]], [[California]]. In 2014, he married [[Carol E. Reiley]].{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/05/13/andrew-ng_n_7267682.html|title=Inside The Mind That Built Google Brain: On Life, Creativity, And Failure|date=May 13, 2015|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=December 19, 2015}} They have two children: a daughter born in 2019{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AndrewYNg/status/1098331008544399360|title=Announcing Nova Ng, our first daughter. Plus, some thoughts on the AI-powered world she will grow up in...|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=February 20, 2019|website=@AndrewYNg|access-date=March 7, 2019}} and a son born in 2021.{{cite news |last=Ng |first=Andrew |date=25 August 2021 |url=https://read.deeplearning.ai/the-batch/issue-106/ |title=Dear friends |work=DeepLearning.ai: The Batch |issue=106}} The ''[[MIT Technology Review]]'' named Ng and Reiley an "AI power couple".{{cite tweet |last=Technology Review |first=MIT |user=techreview |date=Dec 2, 2016 |number=804724229723852801 |access-date=Jun 28, 2023 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230628110150/https://twitter.com/techreview/status/804724229723852801 |archive-date=Jun 28, 2023 |title=Register today to hear power couple @AndrewYNg and @robot_MD speak at #EmTechDigital this March - http://trib.al/WHpHY91 |lang=en }}{{cite tweet |last=Ng |first=Andrew |user=AndrewYNg |date=Dec 2, 2016 |number=804739157935276032 |access-date=Jun 28, 2023 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230628110046/https://twitter.com/AndrewYNg/status/804739157935276032 |archive-date=Jun 28, 2023 |title=MIT Tech Review just called Carol @robot_MD and me a "power couple." :-) |lang=en }} == Career == === Academia and teaching === Ng is a [[professor]] at Stanford University departments of Computer Science and [[electrical engineering]]. He served as the director of the [[Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory]] (SAIL), where he taught students and undertook research related to [[data mining]], [[big data]], and machine learning. His machine learning course CS229 at Stanford is the most popular course offered on campus with over 1,000 students enrolling some years.{{cite news |last=Kosner |first=Anthony Wing |date=December 29, 2013 |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonykosner/2013/12/29/why-is-machine-learning-cs-229-the-most-popular-course-at-stanford/ |title=Why Is Machine Learning (CS 229) The Most Popular Course At Stanford? |work=Forbes}}{{cite web |url=http://cs229.stanford.edu/ |title=CS229: Machine Learning |website=cs229.stanford.edu |access-date=April 17, 2019}} As of 2020, three of most popular courses on Coursera are Ng's: Machine Learning (#1), AI for Everyone (#5), Neural Networks and Deep Learning (#6).{{Cite web|last=Mundial|first=Foro Económico|date=2020-10-27|title=Coursera's Most Popular Online Courses|url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/358518|access-date=2020-12-26|website=Entrepreneur|language=en}} In 2008, his group at Stanford was one of the first in the US to start advocating the use of [[Graphics processing unit|GPUs]] in deep learning.{{Citation needed|date=September 2023}} The rationale was that an efficient computation infrastructure could speed up [[statistical model]] training by orders of magnitude, ameliorating some of the scaling issues associated with big data. At the time it was a controversial and risky decision, but since then and following Ng's lead, GPUs have become a cornerstone in the field. Since 2017, Ng has been advocating the shift to [[high-performance computing]] (HPC) for scaling up deep learning and accelerating progress in the field.{{citation needed |date=March 2024}} In 2012, along with Stanford computer scientist [[Daphne Koller]] he cofounded and was CEO of [[Coursera]], a website that offers free online courses to everyone.{{failed reference|date=May 2020}} It took off with over 100,000 students registered for Ng's popular CS229A course.{{Cite news |last=Friedman |first=Thomas L. |date=May 15, 2012 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/16/opinion/friedman-come-the-revolution.html |title=Opinion: Come the Revolution |work=The New York Times |access-date=February 19, 2018 |issn=0362-4331}} Today, several million people have enrolled in Coursera courses, making the site one of the leading [[massive open online course]]s (MOOCs) in the world. === Industry === From 2011 to 2012, he worked at [[Google]], where he founded and directed the [[Google Brain]] Deep Learning Project with [[Jeff Dean (computer scientist)|Jeff Dean]], Greg Corrado, and Rajat Monga. In 2014, he joined [[Baidu]] as chief scientist, and carried out research related to big data and AI.{{cite web|url=https://www.recode.net/2014/5/16/11626966/baidu-hires-coursera-founder-andrew-ng-to-start-massive-research-lab|title=Baidu Hires Coursera Founder Andrew Ng to Start Massive Research Lab|last=Gannes|first=Liz|date=May 16, 2014|website=Recode|access-date=August 29, 2017}} There he set up several research teams for things like [[Facial recognition system|facial recognition]] and Melody, an AI [[chatbot]] for [[Health care|healthcare]]. He also developed for the company the AI platform called DuerOS and other technologies that positioned Baidu ahead of Google in the discourse and development of AI.{{Cite book |last=Webb |first=Amy |title=The Big Nine: How the Tech Titans and Their Thinking Machines Could Warp Humanity |publisher=PublicAffairs |year=2019 |isbn=978-1-5417-7374-5 |location=New York |language=en}} In March 2017, he announced his resignation from Baidu.{{cite web|title=Opening a new chapter of my work in AI |url=https://medium.com/@andrewng/opening-a-new-chapter-of-my-work-in-ai-c6a4d1595d7b| year=2017 |access-date=May 16, 2014}} He soon afterward launched Deeplearning.AI, an online series of deep learning courses (including the AI for Good Specialization).{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@andrewng/deeplearning-ai-announcing-new-deep-learning-courses-on-coursera-43af0a368116|title=deeplearning.ai: Announcing new Deep Learning courses on Coursera|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=August 8, 2017|website=Medium|access-date=February 19, 2018}} Then Ng launched Landing AI, which provides AI-powered [[SaaS]] products.{{Cite web |last=Lardinois |first=Frederic |date=2019-08-21 |title=Andrew Ng's AI companies expand to Medellin, Colombia |url=https://techcrunch.com/2019/08/21/andrew-ngs-ai-companies-expand-to-medellin-colombia/ |access-date=2023-06-02 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}} In January 2018, Ng unveiled the AI Fund, raising $175 million to invest in new [[Startup company|startups]].{{cite news |last=Frank |first=Blair Hanley |date=January 30, 2018 |url=https://venturebeat.com/2018/01/30/andrew-ng-unveils-the-ai-fund-with-175-million-to-back-new-startups/ |title=Andrew Ng unveils the AI Fund, with $175 million to back new startups |website=VentureBeat |access-date=February 19, 2018}} In November 2021, Landing AI secured a $57 million round of series A funding led by McRock Capital, to help manufacturers adopt computer vision.{{Cite web |date=2021-11-08 |title=MLOps platform Landing AI raises $57M to help manufacturers adopt computer vision |url=https://venturebeat.com/2021/11/08/mlops-platform-landing-ai-raises-57m-to-help-manufacturers-adopt-computer-vision/|access-date=2021-11-09 |website=VentureBeat |language=en-US}} == Research == Ng researches primarily in [[machine learning]], [[deep learning]], [[machine perception]], [[computer vision]], and [[natural language processing]]; and is one of the world's most famous and influential computer scientists.{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/andrew-ng-ai-artificial-intelligence-playbook-2018-12|title=One of the world's most famous computer scientists reveals his 'playbook' for bringing AI to every business|work=Business Insider|year=2018}} He's frequently won best paper awards at academic conferences and has had a huge impact on the field of AI, computer vision, and robotics.{{Cite web|title=Andrew Ng – Publications|url=http://www.robotics.stanford.edu/~ang/papers.php|access-date=2020-12-26|website=www.robotics.stanford.edu}}{{Cite web|title=publications|url=http://ai.stanford.edu/~pabbeel/publications.html|access-date=2020-12-26|website=ai.stanford.edu}} During graduate school, together with [[David M. Blei]] and [[Michael I. Jordan]], Ng co-authored the influential paper that introduced [[latent Dirichlet allocation]] (LDA) for his thesis on reinforcement learning for drones.David M. Blei, Andrew Y. Ng, Michael I. Jordan. Latent Dirichlet allocation. The Journal of Machine Learning Research, Volume 3, January 3, 2003, which is one of the two papers that independently discovered [[Latent Dirichlet allocation]] His early work includes the Stanford Autonomous Helicopter project, which developed one of the most capable autonomous helicopters in the world.{{cite news| url=http://chronicle.com/article/From-Self-Flying-Helicopters/134666/| work=Chronicle of Higher Education |year=2012 |title=From Self-Flying Helicopters to Classrooms of the Future}}{{cite web |url=http://heli.stanford.edu |title=Stanford Autonomous Helicopter Project}} He was the leading scientist and principal investigator on the STAIR (Stanford Artificial Intelligence Robot) project,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/18/technology/18brain.html |work=The New York Times |last=Markoff |first=John |author-link=John Markoff |title=Brainy Robots Start Stepping Into Daily Life |date=July 18, 2006}} which resulted in [[Robot Operating System]] (ROS), a widely used [[open source software]] [[robotics]] platform. His vision to build an AI robot and put a robot in every home inspired Scott Hassan to back him and create [[Willow Garage]].{{Cite book |last=Markoff |first=John |author-link=John Markoff |year=2015 |title=Machines of Loving Grace: The Quest for Common Ground between humans and robots |publisher=[[HarperCollins]] |isbn=978-0-06-226668-2 |location=New York|pages=}} He is also one of the founding team members for the Stanford WordNet project, which uses machine learning to expand the [[Princeton University|Princeton]] [[WordNet]] database created by [[Christiane Fellbaum]].{{cite web|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~rion/swn/|title=The Stanford Wordnet Project|website=ai.stanford.edu|access-date=April 17, 2019}} In 2011, Ng founded the [[Google Brain]] project at [[Google]], which developed large-scale artificial [[neural network]]s using Google's distributed computing infrastructure.{{cite news |title=Google's Lab of Wildest Dreams |work=The New York Times |last1=Miller |first1=Claire |last2=Bilton |first2=Nick |date=November 3, 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/14/technology/at-google-x-a-top-secret-lab-dreaming-up-the-future.html }} Among its notable results was a neural network trained using [[deep learning]] algorithms on 16,000 [[CPU core]]s, which learned to recognize cats after watching only [[YouTube]] videos, and without ever having been told what a "cat" is.{{cite news |title=How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000 |work=The New York Times |last=Markoff |first=John |author-link=John Markoff |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/26/technology/in-a-big-network-of-computers-evidence-of-machine-learning.html |date=June 25, 2012 }}{{cite arXiv |title=Building High-level Features Using Large Scale Unsupervised Learning |last1=Ng |first1=Andrew |last2=Dean |first2=Jeff |eprint=1112.6209|year=2012 |class=cs.LG}} The project's technology is also currently used in the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] operating system's [[speech recognition]] system.{{cite web|url=http://googleresearch.blogspot.com/2012/08/speech-recognition-and-deep-learning.html|title=Speech Recognition and Deep Learning|work=Google Research Blog|date=August 6, 2012|access-date=January 29, 2013}} == Online education: massive open online course == {{external media |width=210px |float=right |audio1=[http://degreeoffreedom.org/interview-with-coursera-co-founder-andrew-ng/ Interview with Coursera Co-Founder Andrew Ng], Degree of Freedom{{cite web |title=Interview with Coursera Co-Founder Andrew Ng |publisher=Degree of Freedom |date=May 17, 2013 |url=http://degreeoffreedom.org/interview-with-coursera-co-founder-andrew-ng/ |access-date=May 19, 2013}}}}In 2011, Stanford launched a total of three [[massive open online course]] (MOOCs) on machine learning (CS229a), [[database]]s, and AI, taught by Ng, [[Peter Norvig]], [[Sebastian Thrun]], and [[Jennifer Widom]].{{cite web|url=https://www.andrewng.org/portfolio/origins-of-the-modern-mooc-xmooc/|title=Origins of the Modern MOOC|last1=Ng|first1=Andrew|last2=Widom|first2=Jennifer|access-date=April 17, 2019|archive-date=June 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170602043251/http://www.andrewng.org/portfolio/origins-of-the-modern-mooc-xmooc/|url-status=dead}}{{cite web|url=https://ai.stanford.edu/~ang/papers/mooc14-OriginsOfModernMOOC.pdf|title=Origins of the Modern MOOC (xMOOC)|last1=Ng|first1=Andrew|last2=Widom|first2=Jennifer}} This has led to the modern MOOC movement. Ng taught machine learning and Widom taught databases. The course on AI taught by Thrun led to the genesis of [[Udacity]]. The seeds of massive open online courses (MOOCs) go back a few years before the founding of Coursera in 2012. Two themes emphasized in the founding of modern MOOCs were ''scale'' and ''availability''. By 2023, Ng has notably expanded access to AI education, with an estimated 8 million individuals worldwide taking his courses via platforms like DeepLearning.AI and Coursera. === Founding of Coursera === Ng started the [[Stanford Engineering Everywhere]] (SEE) program, which in 2008 published a number of Stanford courses online for free. Ng taught one of these courses, "Machine Learning", which includes his video lectures, along with the student materials used in the Stanford CS229 class. It offered a similar experience to [[MIT OpenCourseWare]], except it aimed at providing a more "complete course" experience, equipped with lectures, course materials, problems and solutions, etc. The SEE videos were viewed by the millions and inspired Ng to develop and iterate new versions of online tech. Within Stanford, they include [[Daphne Koller]] with her "blended learning experiences" and codesigning a peer-grading system, John Mitchell (Courseware, a [[Learning management system|Learning Management System]]), [[Dan Boneh]] (using machine learning to sync videos, later teaching [[cryptography]] on Coursera), [[Bernd Girod]] (ClassX), and others. Outside Stanford, Ng and Thrun credit [[Sal Khan]] of [[Khan Academy]] as a huge source of inspiration. Ng was also inspired by [[LinkedIn Learning|lynda.com]] and the design of the forums of [[Stack Overflow]]. Widom, Ng, and others were ardent advocates of Khan-styled tablet recordings, and between 2009 and 2011, several hundred hours of lecture videos recorded by Stanford instructors were recorded and uploaded. Ng tested some of the original designs with a local high school to figure the best practices for recording lessons. In October 2011, the "applied" version of the Stanford class (CS229a) was hosted on ml-class.org and launched, with over 100,000 students registered for its first edition. The course featured quizzes and graded programming assignments and became one of the first and most successful massive open online courses (MOOCs) created by a Stanford professor.{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Theresa |date=September–October 2012 |url=http://alumni.stanford.edu/get/page/magazine/article/?article_id=55991 |work=Stanford Magazine |title=Stanford for All}} Two other courses on databases (db-class.org) and AI (ai-class.org) were launched. The ml-class and db-class ran on a platform developed by students, including Frank Chen, Jiquan Ngiam, Chuan-Yu Foo, and Yifan Mai. Word spread through social media and popular press. The three courses were 10 weeks long, and over 40,000 "Statements of Accomplishment" were awarded. Ng tells the following story on the early days of Coursera:{{blockquote|In 2011, I was working with four Stanford students. We were under tremendous pressure to build new features for the 100,000+ students that were already signed up. One of the students (Frank Chen) claims another one (Jiquan Ngiam) frequently stranded him in the Stanford building and refused to give him a ride back to his dorm until very late at night so he had no choice but to stick around and keep working. I neither confirm nor deny this story.{{cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-good-stories-from-the-early-days-of-Coursera|title=What are some good stories from the early days of Coursera? – Quora|website=quora.com|access-date=April 17, 2019}}}} His work subsequently led to his founding of Coursera with Koller in 2012. As of 2019, the two most popular courses on the platform were taught and designed by Ng: "Machine Learning" (#1) and "Neural Networks and Deep Learning" (#2). === Post-Coursera work === In 2019, Ng launched a new course "AI for Everyone". This is a non-technical course designed to help people understand AI's impact on society and its benefits and costs for companies, as well as how they can navigate through this [[technological revolution]].{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@andrewng/announcing-ai-for-everyone-a-new-course-from-deeplearning-ai-44b609c042f|title=Announcing "AI for Everyone": a new course from deeplearning.ai|last=Ng|first=Andrew|date=November 14, 2018|website=Medium|access-date=December 14, 2018}} == Venture capital == Ng is the chair of the board for Woebot Labs, a psychological clinic that uses [[data science]] to provide [[cognitive behavioral therapy]]. It provides a therapy [[chatbot]] to help treat depression, among other things.{{cite web|url=https://woebot.io/|title=Woebot – Your charming robot friend who is here for you, 24/7|website=woebot.io|access-date=April 17, 2019}} He is also a member of the board of directors for [[drive.ai]], which uses AI for [[self-driving car]]s and was acquired by Apple in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrewyng/|title=Andrew Ng LinkedIn page}}{{cite web|url=https://www.drive.ai/|title=The self-driving car is here|website=drive.ai|access-date=April 17, 2019|archive-date=April 17, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190417010512/https://www.drive.ai/|url-status=dead}} Through Landing AI, he also focuses on democratizing AI technology and lowering the barrier for entrance to businesses and developers. == Publications and awards == Ng is also the author or co-author of over 300 publications in [[robotics]], and related fields.{{cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=mG4imMEAAAAJ&oi=sra|title=Andrew Ng – Google Scholar Citations|website=scholar.google.com|access-date=December 14, 2018}} His work in [[computer vision]] and [[deep learning]] has been featured often in press releases and reviews.[http://news.stanford.edu/news/2005/december7/robotsee-120705.html New algorithm improves robot vision] *1995. Bell Atlantic Network Services Scholarship{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Andrew Ng's CV|url=http://ai.stanford.edu/~ang//curriculum-vitae.pdf|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}} *1995, 1996. He has also been the editor of the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR), Associate Editor for the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|IEEE]] Robotics and Automation Society Conference Editorial Board (ICRA), and much more. He has given invited talks at [[NASA]], [[Google]], [[Microsoft]], [[Lockheed Martin]], the [[Max Planck Society]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]], [[University of Pennsylvania|UPenn]], [[Cornell University|Cornell]], [[MIT]], [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]], and dozens of other universities. Outside of the US, he has lectured in Spain, Germany, Israel, China, Korea, and Canada. He has also written for ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'', ''[[HuffPost]]'', ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', ''[[Apple News]]'', and Quora Sessions' Twitter.{{Citation needed|date=March 2024}} He also writes a weekly digital newsletter called ''The Batch''. == Books == He also wrote a book ''Machine Learning Yearning'', a practical guide for those interested in machine learning, which he distributed for free.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlyearning.org/|title=Machine Learning Yearning|year=2017}} In December 2018, he wrote a sequel called ''AI Transformation Playbook''.{{cite web|url=https://landing.ai/ai-transformation-playbook/|title=AI Transformation Playbook How to lead your company into the AI era|date=December 13, 2018|website=Landing AI|access-date=December 14, 2018}} Ng contributed one chapter to ''Architects of Intelligence: The Truth About AI from the People Building it'' (2018) by the American futurist [[Martin Ford (author)|Martin Ford]]. == Views on AI == A real threat is regarding the future of work: "Rather than being distracted by evil killer robots, the challenge to labor caused by these machines is a conversation that academia and industry and government should have."{{Cite news |first=Nick |last=Thieme |date=2017-08-01|title=Zuckerberg and Musk are arguing about the dangers of AI – they're both wrong|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/world/zuckerberg-and-musk-are-arguing-about-the-dangers-of-ai-theyre-both-wrong|access-date=2020-12-26|website=[[The Straits Times]]}} A particular goal of Ng's work is to "democratize" AI learning so that people can learn more about it and understand its benefits.{{Citation needed|date=February 2024}} In a December 2023 [[Financial Times]] interview, Ng highlighted concerns regarding the impact of potential regulations on [[Open source ai|open-source AI]], emphasizing how reporting, licensing, and liability risks could unfairly burden smaller firms and stifle innovation. He argued that regulating basic technologies like open-source models could hinder progress without markedly enhancing safety. Ng advocated for carefully designed regulations to prevent obstacles to the development and distribution of beneficial AI technologies.{{Cite news |last=McMorrow |first=Ryan |date=2023-12-19
